node.title: Fatal Surfside Condo Collapse Occurred Due to Construction of High-Rise Next Door: Lawsuit
node.description: A new lawsuit filed for the victims and family members of Champlain Towers South in Miami said, "the collapse was entirely preventable."

node.title: Drug crisis, corruption and COVID-19 on voters' minds as Tonga heads to the polls
node.description: While climate change and COVID-19 have dominated the news cycle, Tonga's battle with corruption and drug use are also front of mind for voters as they head to the polls.

node.title: As the NT's COVID outbreak grows, so are questions about why this at-risk community isn't in lockdown
node.description: Pressure is growing on the NT government to declare a lockdown in Borroloola, a large remote community with strong links to Robinson River where six Aboriginal people have so far tested positive to COVID amid a Territory cluster.

node.title: The same places keep appearing in most-disadvantaged lists. COVID means it could be getting worse
node.description: The most comprehensive report into disadvantage in Australia reveals disadvantage is not only entrenched in some communities, it also impacts a wide range of factors.

node.title: Managers more likely to think pay is fair - study
node.description: Employees are also more doubtful than managers about their organisation's pay transparency, the study found.

node.title: All Whites finish great year
node.description: When All Whites coach Danny Hay finally gets back to New Zealand to enjoy a much needed Christmas break with his family next month, you wouldn't blame him if he took some time to toast himself, for a…

node.title: America's Cup continues to cut costs
node.description: The rules for the next America's Cup have been released but the wait continues for a venue.

node.title: Covid-19 wrap: Auckland on path to reopening, vaccine pass launched
node.description: Schools have reopened for younger students, the Auckland boundary is set to reopen mid-December for a month, and a Covid-19 vaccine pass has come into play.

node.title: Bishops approve Communion guidelines after debate on Biden's eligibility
node.description: Catholic bishops from across the U.S. voted on a document outlining the meaning of the sacrament of Communion and who should receive it.

node.title: She Shaped the Sound of ‘Cowboy Bebop,’ Again
node.description: Yoko Kanno has become one of Japan’s foremost composers since she created the eclectic score for the anime series “Cowboy Bebop.” She returned for Netflix’s live-action version.

node.title: What if Your Kids Never Let You Sleep Again?
node.description: You can’t control your children’s sleep. And you probably don’t have to.

node.title: 2 Men Convicted of Killing Malcolm X Will Be Exonerated After 55 Years
node.description: The convictions of two men are expected to be thrown out after a 22-month investigation, validating long-held doubts about who killed the civil rights leader.

node.title: Does Your Dog Deserve a Private Park?
node.description: When no ordinary fire hydrant will do, New York City offers multiple members-only dog parks, for annual fees ranging from free to $2,200.

node.title: Catholic Bishops Avoid Confrontation With Biden Over Communion
node.description: In a vote, they endorsed new guidance on offering holy communion to public figures but did not overtly mention the president or other officials who support abortion rights.

node.title: U.S. Journalist Danny Fenster 'Incredibly Fortunate' to Be Home After Myanmar Imprisonment
node.description: "I can't believe the amount of effort that went into it that was necessary to make this happen–overwhelming gratitude," Fenster said.

node.title: Woman Says She Woke Up With Bite Marks After Passing Out at Club in Viral Video
node.description: The TikToker speculates that she was drugged during her night out at the club, as she has no memory of the incident.

node.title: Watch N.Y. Mayor-Elect Eric Adams Gift Stephen Colbert Fake Bag of Weed on 'Late Show'
node.description: Adams also brought several packs of rolling papers and a blanket as gifts for Stephen Colbert.

node.title: Man Sentenced for Hate Crime Against Teenager, Stabbed Her and Attempted to Gouge Her Eyes
node.description: "This was by any measure one of the most vicious and brutal violent attacks we have ever seen," the Westchester County District Attorney said in a statement.

node.title: 2 Sentenced for Scamming Mostly Elderly of More Than $700K By Claiming They Won Lottery
node.description: Jason Wedderburn joins his co-conspirator, Kayan Kitson, in jail after being sentenced to three years.

node.title: Fans Can Now Get Paid $50 an Hour to Dress Up As Ross Geller's Holiday Armadillo From 'Friends'
node.description: The iconic holiday armadillo outfit worn by Ross Geller, played by David Schwimmer, appears in season 7 , episode 10.

node.title: QAnon Shaman Jacob Chansley, Who Asked Trump for Pardon, Gets 41 Months for Capitol Riot
node.description: Chansley denied he's a "dangerous criminal," an "insurrectionist" or a "domestic terrorist" but took responsibility for his actions during a court hearing.

node.title: Joe Biden Calls for Probe Into Whether Illegal Conduct Is to Blame for High Gas Prices
node.description: Today, the average price for a gallon of regular unleaded gas is $3.413—more than a dollar higher than the average price one year ago.

node.title: Trump Tells McConnell to Resign if Biden Social Bill Passes, Vows to Withhold Endorsements
node.description: Trump, who threatened to withhold endorsements from Congressional Republicans, called McConnell a "fool" who should have resigned a "long time ago."

node.title: Fijian Drua could play at home in 2022
node.description: The Fijian Drua could yet play on home soil in the inaugural campaign in Super Rugby Pacific.

node.title: Body found in Clutha River believed to be missing Alexandra man Wayne Hammond
node.description: Police found the body in the Clutha River in Central Otago about 1.5km from the Roxburgh Dam.

node.title: Biogen’s Alzheimer’s drug is unlikely to win E.U. approval.
node.description: The drug, Aduhelm, has been mired in controversy since it was in approved in the United States in June.

node.title: The Wisconsin National Guard has been placed on standby ahead of the verdict.
node.description: Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin activated about 500 members of his state’s National Guard ahead of the verdict in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial in Kenosha.

node.title: Pentagon Chief Expected to Discuss 2019 Airstrike That Killed Dozens
node.description: A Times investigation found that the bombing in Syria was carried out by a shadowy Special Operations unit.

node.title: Scientists Warn of Bacterial 'Alien Invasion' Caused by Space Missions
node.description: Space missions could also carry "bacterial invaders" to unspoiled alien worlds such as Mars and the moon.

node.title: Judge Rules Refugee Can Be Deported for Lying About ISIS Involvement on Immigration Papers
node.description: A federal judge ruled Omar Abdulsattar Ameen is eligible for deportation to Iraq or Turkey after lying about having contact with anyone from terrorist groups.

node.title: Texas Library Cancel Children's Event After Transgender Misinformation Sparks Threats
node.description: Denton Public Library has defended its decision to initially hold the Rainbow StoryTime event despite backlash due to "incorrect information."

node.title: Mississippi to Conduct First Execution Since 2012, Inmate Calls Himself 'Worthy of Death'
node.description: David Cox, who murdered his estranged wife, is scheduled for execution by lethal injection at 6 p.m. CST at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman.

node.title: NFL Mandates New Testing Protocol Amid Uptick in COVID Cases, Holiday Season
node.description: Regardless of vaccine status, players, coaches and other NFL personnel will be required to wear masks during the week after Thanksgiving.

node.title: 'She's alright': Queen makes first in-person engagement since hospitalisation last month
node.description: The 95-year-old monarch was forced to pull out of Remembrance Sunday services last weekend after suffering a sprained back, Buckingham Palace said.

node.title: U.S. Catholic bishops to vote on who should receive Communion
node.description: Bishops continue debating whether Catholic politicians like President Biden, who support abortion rights, should be barred from Communion.

node.title: Thanksgiving for Beginners
node.description: Need a little assistance? Eric Kim has seven recipes and an invaluable guide to get you through the meal.

node.title: In Central Italy, a Dance Party By the Sea
node.description: Last month at La Posta Vecchia, the hotelier Marie-Louise Sciò threw a rollicking reunion for friends and family.

node.title: The DNA of Roma People Has Long Been Misused, Scientists Reveal
node.description: An op-ed in Nature calls for higher ethical standards in the usage and analysis of genetic information from the Romani, a marginalized group in Europe.

node.title: Amazon, railing against high fees, will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain.
node.description: For years merchants have complained about transaction fees that eat into their revenue, but having Amazon take up the fight may ratchet up the pressure. The change will come into effect Jan. 19.

node.title: Miramax Sues Quentin Tarantino Over Planned ‘Pulp Fiction’ NFTs
node.description: The director announced this month he was selling nonfungible tokens based on the screenplay for his 1994 movie. Miramax asserted in court documents it still has “broad rights” to the film.

node.title: Who are the jurors in the Kyle Rittenhouse trial?
node.description: The jury is made up of seven women and five men. They began deliberating on Tuesday morning, and were to continue on Wednesday.

node.title: House is Set to Censure Paul Gosar for Violent Video
node.description: The Democratic-led House is expected to formally rebuke the Arizona Republican, meting out a rarely used punishment for the first time in over a decade.

node.title: U.N. Says Iran Adding to Uranium Stockpile, But Still Cannot Verify Exact Numbers
node.description: A U.N. agency said it was unable to specify exactly how large the cache has become because of restrictions imposed on. inspectors by Tehran earlier this year.

node.title: Migrants Removed From Belarus Border Camp by Bus, Deescalating Tensions With Poland
node.description: A day before being forced to leave the border camp, migrants were seen throwing rocks at Polish forces who used water cannons and tear gas on the migrants.

node.title: French TV Pundit Weighing Presidential Run Goes on Trial for Calling Migrant Kids Thieves
node.description: Eric Zemmour, far-right TV pundit, faces his third hate speech conviction for calling unaccompanied migrant children thieves, murderers and rapists.

node.title: How China's New Data Law Disrupts the Already Congested Supply Chain Ahead of the Holidays
node.description: Under the new law, foreign shipping companies are being blocked from accessing data necessary to plan shipping routes to avoid delays and congested ports.

node.title: James Clyburn Accuses GOP of Staying Silent on Gosar Video: 'What Is That About?'
node.description: "When someone sends out a tweet, or any other illustration, of him or her murdering somebody on the House floor, that, to me, goes far beyond the pale,"  said the House Majority Whip about Arizona GOP Rep. Paul Gosar.

node.title: Washington Zoo Welcomes First Baby Armadillo in 116-year History
node.description: Southern three-banded armadillos are classes as "near threatened", and the pup was born as a part of the Association of Zoos & Aquariums' Species Survival Plan.

node.title: Suspected Poacher Missing After Jumping Into Crocodile-infested Lake to Escape Rangers
node.description: Nile crocodiles, common in the iSimangaliso wildlife park, are the most deadly of all crocodilians, accounting for hundreds of human deaths every year.

node.title: Miss Universe Pageant, Held in Israel for First Time, Draws Boycott Calls for Contestants
node.description: South Africa has already withdrawn from the pageant's 70th edition, citing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

node.title: China Not Looking to 'Surpass or Replace' United States, Beijing Says
node.description: China's Foreign Ministry echoed recent comments by Xi Jinping, who said both China and the U.S. stood to lose from confrontation.

node.title: GOP Tried to Poach Sinema 'Multiple Times' but She Shut Them Down: 'Why Would I Do That?'
node.description: Fellow senator and Democratic moderate Joe Manchin said he's been approached about switching parties "every day."

node.title: Senior cleric linked to terror network behind the Bali nightclub bombings charged over alleged sham charity
node.description: The charity used the cover of social and educational motives to collect funds and divert some of them to terror group Jemaah Islamiyah, which is regrouping after its spiritual leader Abu Bakar Bashir was released from prison this year.

node.title: "Buy now, pay later" plans may have a catch: Your credit score
node.description: Companies including Amazon, Walmart and Mastercard are hopping on the BNPL bandwagon. Here's what consumers should know.

node.title: Poland warns escalating border crisis with Belarus could last "months"
node.description: Polish forces unleashed tear gas, water cannon and rubber bullets on migrants as tension mounts along the heavily guarded border between the EU and Russian-backed Belarus.

node.title: Queen Elizabeth II seen for 1st time since back sprain derailed plans
node.description: The British monarch, 95, cancelled plans over the weekend to attend a Remembrance Sunday service, which had been her expected return to official engagements.

node.title: American Trevor Reed ends hunger strike in Russian prison, lawyers say
node.description: The former U.S. Marine, jailed for 9 years for an assault he says he can't remember, had stopped eating to protest purported abuse at the hands of his Russian jailers.

node.title: Kyle Rittenhouse jury enters second day of deliberations
node.description: Opposing protesters for and against a guilty verdict have gathered outside the Kenosha courthouse.

node.title: Video shows buck inside church on first day of hunting season
node.description: "I was a little sad that we didn't actually take a little time to pray with him before he went out to face the world on the opening day of deer season," the pastor said.

node.title: Britney Spears opens up about "demoralizing" conservatorship

node.title: "Harry Potter" stars to reunite for 20th anniversary special
node.description: The retrospective will feature interviews with many of the film's actors and a look at the making of the series.

node.title: U.S. closes first temporary housing site for Afghan evacuees
node.description: More than 25,000 Afghan evacuees have departed military sites to start new lives in communities across the U.S.

node.title: "QAnon Shaman" to be sentenced for role in January 6 attack
node.description: A federal judge is set to sentence Jacob Chansley for his role in the January 6 attack on the Capitol.

node.title: FDA may authorize Pfizer booster shots for all adults this week
node.description: The drugmaker filed​ for emergency use authorization last week.

node.title: 86-year-old wins "Miss Holocaust Survivor" pageant
node.description: Some feel the pageant could cheapen the memory of the the lives lost, but others say it honors the dwindling number of women who endured the Holocaust.

node.title: More than 100,000 Americans died of drug overdoses in one year
node.description: Drug overdoses now surpass deaths from car crashes, guns and even flu and pneumonia.

node.title: Frida Kahlo's self portrait sells for nearly $35 million
node.description: The self-portrait was one of the Mexican painter's last self-portraits before her death.

node.title: House Hunting in Italy: See-Through Floors in Milan for $1.8 Million
node.description: New development is changing the face of Milan, one of Italy’s most expensive cities, though price growth is slowing after a frenzied year of buying.

node.title: What to Listen To: Five Audiobooks
node.description: Here are five new audiobooks to listen to this week.

node.title: How College Sports May Change Under Proposed N.C.A.A. Rule Revisions
node.description: The notoriously bureaucratic N.C.A.A. is gearing up for debates about what it should look like going forward.

node.title: With Halo Infinite, Microsoft Hopes to Rekindle Its Flagship Game
node.description: Though interest in Halo has waned over the years, the company is banking on a new version to goose sales of its Xbox and subscription gaming service.

node.title: Mr. The Untold Story of Von Dutch
node.description: Behind the brand that made trucker hats hot in the early 2000s is a messy corporate origin tale, filled with sabotage and greed.

node.title: As gas prices surge, President Biden asks the F.T.C. to investigate ‘illegal conduct.’
node.description: President Biden asked the Federal Trade Commission to look into whether big oil companies are fueling a spike in gas prices.

node.title: Overdose Deaths Reached Record High as the Pandemic Spread
node.description: More than 100,000 Americans died from drug overdoses in the yearlong period ending in April, government researchers said.

node.title: How do jury deliberations work?
node.description: The 12 jurors in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial are to consider only the evidence presented in court as they work toward verdicts on five criminal counts that must each be decided unanimously.

node.title: Deaf Football Team Brings Pride to Riverside Community
node.description: A remarkable undefeated season for the California School for the Deaf football team brightens a community ravaged by the pandemic.

node.title: Professor Cited as Corruption Expert Is Sentenced for Money Laundering
node.description: A former University of Miami international studies professor used bank accounts in his name and the name of a company he created to launder about $2.5 million, prosecutors said.

node.title: U.S. Covid cases are increasing again
node.description: The latest news and data from the team tracking the coronavirus.

node.title: The E.U. adopts new sanctions against Belarus.

node.title: A Syrian teenager is buried in Poland, and a pair of brothers are rescued from a forest.

node.title: Raúl Rivero, Disenchanted Poet of the Cuban Revolution, Dies at 75
node.description: A leading journalistic voice who broke with the Castro regime, he gained wide recognition for his protests, was jailed as a dissident and went into exile.

node.title: Who Is Jessica Watkins? NASA Astronaut To Become First Black Woman on The ISS
node.description: Watkins will serve as a mission specialist on the upcoming SpaceX Crew-4 launch to the International Space Station. The journey will mark the first time the astronaut has traveled to space.

node.title: What Is Protollin? Nasal Alzheimer's vaccine to Be Tested in Human Trials
node.description: The trials are set to be the first in which humans are given a nasal vaccine in order to treat Alzheimer's.

node.title: Symptoms of Tapeworm in the Brain Explained as Man Diagnosed After Seizures
node.description: After suffering a violent seizure that left him shaking on his bedroom floor and "talking gibberish," a 38-year-old Massachusetts man was taken to hospital where he was diagnosed with neurocysticercosis.

node.title: Peng Shuai Missing Update As Concerns Grow Over Chinese Tennis Star's Disappearance
node.description: The former doubles no. 1 has not been seen or heard from since making sexual assault allegations against a former high-ranking Chinese official.

node.title: Europe Urges Oklahoma Governor to Stop Julius Jones Execution
node.description: Stavros Lambrinidis, the European Union's ambassador to the U.S., sent a letter to Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt asking him to grant clemency to Jones.

node.title: Fox News Coverage of Critical Race Theory Plummeted After Virginia Election
node.description: The network is not giving anywhere near as much attention on the theory being taught in schools following Glenn Youngkin's victory.

node.title: Support for Stricter Gun Laws in U.S. Falls to Lowest Ranking Since 2014: Poll
node.description: According to the poll, 91 percent of Democrats support stricter gun laws, while only 24 percent of Republicans agree.

node.title: Jail for Melbourne man who flew around world to groom and abuse underage girls
node.description: The County Court heard the 43-year-old groomed five vulnerable teenage girls online, with one victim saying the abuse has left her feeling "completely alone".

node.title: Push to get businesses, banks to help end scam text messages
node.description: The pandemic is providing fertile ground for an uptick in cybercrime, with scammers targeting Australians with dodgy texts and robocalls — something the federal Opposition wants to stop.

node.title: Restrictions may lift earlier as Victoria kicks vaccination goals, but health workers urge more protection
node.description: Mask use will be scaled down in Victoria, and venues will be able to operate at greater capacity as part of a further easing of restrictions that could be in place for the weekend.

node.title: U.N. to Elon Musk: Here's how $6.6 billion would help fight hunger
node.description: The Tesla CEO challenged the United Nations to break down how a mega-donation from him would avert famine. So it did.

node.title: Leonids Meteor Shower 2021: Watch It Peak in Night Skies Overnight
node.description: If you’re willing to stay up into the early hours of Wednesday morning, you may get a chance to spot fireballs streaking across the sky.

node.title: Subway Fare Increase ‘Off the Table’ Thanks to Infrastructure Bill
node.description: Officials said that federal money, including the $1 trillion infrastructure bill, will help the M.T.A. keep fares stable for at least six months and avoid service cuts.

node.title: Researchers Identify Dozens of Native Students Who Died at Nebraska School
node.description: Using digitized records and newspaper clippings, researchers pieced together the history of the Genoa U.S. Indian Industrial School, a government-run institution that closed in 1934.

node.title: The Netherlands is maxing out its coronavirus testing capacity.
node.description: Soaring demand and a shortage of workers have made appointments almost impossible to find.

node.title: Woman Branded 'Catfish' Hilariously Calculates Tinder Match's Real Height From His Photos
node.description: Paris Campbell was called a "catfish" on the app, but had the last laugh when she figured out the true height of the man who claimed to be 6'1" online.

node.title: US and China announce easing of restrictions on each other's journalists
node.description: All details are yet to be firmed up and made public and there is yet to be a timeline for bringing the changes in, even after a year of tense discussions over the new arrangements.

node.title: Former minister Adem Somyurek will vote against Andrews government's pandemic laws
node.description: The Andrews government's pandemic laws are in tatters with former minister Adem Somyurek declaring he will vote against the bill in its current form.

node.title: Fugitive couple sentenced to prison over COVID fraud scheme
node.description: Richard Ayvazyan and his wife, Marietta Terabelian, remain at large after the FBI says they removed their electronic tracking bracelets in August.
